awd_titl_txt: EAGER: AI-DCL: Exploratory research on the use of AI at the intersection of homelessness and child maltreatment
awd_abstract_narration:
Homelessness and housing insecurity present fundamental challenges for the delivery of social services. The absence of stable accommodations increases the risks of poor outcomes for all members of the household, including children, experiencing this insecurity. This project is an exploratory study in the use of techniques from artificial intelligence (AI) to improve early screening and the delivery of targeted assistance to households that are at risk of future homelessness and child maltreatment. The team will seek to develop novel methods for allocation of scarce housing-support resources to at-risk households, taking into account considerations of both overall efficiency and fairness. This work will necessitate novel problem formulation and algorithm development in AI as well as creating new ethical methods for deciding on how to effectively deliver social services taking into account the vast complexity of human behavior. Moreover, reducing the risks of homelessness and child maltreatment are critical societal goals with the potential to substantively improve the lives of many of our most vulnerable citizens.

This project will explore the feasibility of using novel algorithmic techniques to inform societal decision-making on the allocation of scarce resources, with the specific goal of improving service system outcomes for both homelessness and child welfare. The team's focus will be on homelessness prevention interventions that offer timely, non-reoccurring resources to stabilize families at risk of experiencing housing crises; examples of such resources include landlord mediation, one-time rent or utility payments, and moving expenses. They will leverage unique datasets on child welfare and homelessness in the research, and use these to inform the design of machine learning approaches to prediction of outcomes (specifically, repeat episodes of homelessness and future interactions with child protective services), and optimization techniques that leverage these predictions in order to decide on which households to target for prevention interventions. The interplay of prediction and optimization, in a context where the overall allocation must both improve social welfare (measured along multiple dimensions) and satisfy notions of  fairness, equity, and local justice in the allocation of scarce resources, is a challenging domain for AI.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the use of AI in the delivery of customized housing assistance to those at risk of, or experiencing, homelessness in order to improve outcomes both in terms of overall rates of homelessness and inequities experienced by different intersectional groups.
We focused on (1) understanding the effects and fairness implications of assignment policies on different types of households, including those with and without children, (2) better understanding decision maker preferences about which types of households to prioritize for scarce resources like supportive housing, and (3) initial development of a community- and data-driven approach to homelessness prevention that generates transparent prioritization rules with consideration of equity of outcomes among subpopulations of interest.
Our investigations revealed many interesting results, published in venues including ACM FAccT, ACM EC, the Journal of the American Medical Informatics Institute, and the Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research, among others. We highlight a few of those here, corresponding to the three foci above.
First, we were able to obtain a new characterization of tradeoffs between different group fairness metrics in societal resource allocation problems. We have shown that different notions of fairness cannot be simultaneously satisfied in a class of assignment problems with at least three possible interventions, as long as there is any heterogeneity in group responses to different interventions. Using our homelessness data, we have shown that this impossibility is more than just a theoretical curiosity and could influence how one views the fairness of different allocations across sociodemographic groups (e.g. single women with children versus without). This work was published at FAccT 2022.
Second, we have demonstrated that, in tasks where laypeople must select among households to receive more scarce resources, there are massive effects of both framing and providing quantitative outcome predictions. Our main findings are (1) When vulnerability or outcomes are quantitatively conceptualized and presented, humans (at a single point in time) are remarkably consistent in making either vulnerability- or outcome-oriented decisions. (2) Prior exposure to quantitative outcome predictions has a significant effect and changes the preferences of human decision-makers from vulnerability-oriented to outcome-oriented about one-third of the time. (3) Presenting algorithmically-derived risk predictions in addition to household descriptions reinforces decision-maker preferences. Among the vulnerability-oriented, presenting the risk predictions leads to an increase in allocations to the more vulnerable household, whereas among the outcome-oriented it leads to a decrease in allocations to the more vulnerable household. This work was published at EC 2022.
Third, our analysis of data on the effects of different interventions across different intersectional groups revealed several interesting patterns. First, homelessness prevention benefited households who could access it. Second, there were some differential effects across different types of homeless households. Households with comorbid health conditions avoid homelessness most when provided longer-term supportive housing, while families with children fare best in short-term rentals. We found that simple, transparent prioritization rules derived from these data-driven insights can reduce community-wide homelessness in simulations. Moreover, such prioritization counterfactually mitigates observed reentry disparities for female and unaccompanied youth without excluding Black and families with children. This work was published in JAMIA in 2023.
The project also enabled work on various related projects, and informed related work on homelessness service provision that appeared at other venues, including AAAI and IJCAI. The project supported the training of several graduate and undergraduate students. Notably, Amanda Kube, who worked on this project, successfully defended her PhD as the first graduate of the new PhD program in the Division of Computational and Data Sciences at WashU.
We disseminated the results of our research broadly in both the academic and practitioner communities, including through conference presentations, invited talks at universities and companies, practitioner conferences, and tutorials at conferences including INFORMS and AAMAS. During the COVID outbreak, we worked to translate research into data-driven decision-making on allocating scarce resources to prevent eviction among families. Dr. Fowler co-authored an op-ed published in the St. Louis American illustrating equitable and efficient policy responses for COVID-related evictions, and the work informed local decisions-makers on designing evaluatable service delivery.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/03/2024
Modified by: Sanmay Das
